Adapt_main_4_mc_27_TEXT: COVID destroyed our previously very business and I dont know that we can recover
Adapt_Main_5_open: Grant money is what is needed at this point. This is a fitness business and the State of Colorado shut us down completely for 3 months and severely limited our capacity for another 10 months and then encouraged people to stay away from indoor fitness facilities after that. The State gave us no way to cover rent and the Federal Govt largely excluded fitness businesses from the PPP because our "employees" are fitness teachers who are all Independent Contractors not Employees. I am quite certain that no one will even read this survey and no one cares. And this is simply a marketing ploy. If thats not the case ... then prove me wrong and send me an email.

Bhea_Opres_6_open: I am happy and able to make enough money to survive. I.e., my fear level is low.
Tech_tool_3_mc_23: Using anti-malware/virus software on all computers used for my business
Tech_tool_3_mc_22_TEXT: I have decided to go low tech and I do as much as I can without using technology, including bookkeeping, keeping track of clients, etc. Being a sole proprietor with no employees makes this possible. I like simple. I like things I can control.
Adapt_main_3_mc_15_TEXT: Change locations to be at home. Now that delta is a problem, I might have to shut down again.
Adapt_main_4_mc_27_TEXT: I'm a hands-on service provider (massage), helping each person in a small enclosed room. Not safe.
Adapt_Main_5_open: If I could afford to buy a house in Boulder (and have money to maintain it), where I could have a separate entrance for massage clients, then it would be easier for me to practice. Renting office space makes me have to work way too hard and it's throwing money away. However, it's impossible for me to buy a house in Boulder. With continually rising taxes and HOA fees, it's even a challenge to stay in the condo I own.

Demo_main_1_mc_1: Denver (Adams, Arapahoe, Boulder, Broomfield, Clear Creek, Denver, Douglas, Gilpin, and Jefferson)
Bhea_Opres_6_open: My business is based on the ability of musical acts to be able to tour. That's still not able to happen on a large scale, so my business is still severely impacted due to the pandemic. Revenue dropped 80% in both 2020 & 2021. Can't survive much longer without having to abandon what it took 24 years to build.
Tech_tool_3_mc_17: Backing up business data and information
Tech_tool_3_mc_19: Training employees on phishing emails and cyber security
Tech_tool_3_mc_23: Using anti-malware/virus software on all computers used for my business
Adapt_main_4_mc_22: Uncertain market demand for your business
Adapt_main_4_mc_27_TEXT: Lack of 'product' because bands are not touring at the regular pace.
Adapt_Main_5_open:
My business counts on bands being able to tour and create live in studio performances. Over the past 24 years, I've managed to weather any number of storms, even the economic downturns. But the pandemic stopped bands from touring, thus, no live in-studio performances. They are beginning again, but at tis rate things couldn't possibly get back to any version of 'normal' for my business until mid-2022. I've already blown through my savings. I applied for help, but as a sole proprietor my options were severely limited.
I blame Trump's leadership and for making this a political issue, when it should have only ever been a healthcare issue. & unfortunately it continues today, with those who won't get vaccinated when they are able, they are putting everyone at risk again &, for some of us, our livelihoods. I don't know what to do at this point? I'm at the mercy of other citizens (on a large scale) doing the right thing & unfortunately, enough have not done so as of yet.


It also would have been great if the programs put in place by Congress would have helped small businesses more. I saw a story on the news the other night showing how someone faked applications & got away with 1.2million in untraceable funds from PPP Loans. I've built my company & paid taxes for 24 years. I qualified for a whopping $7001.00? How is that fair? It's just frustrating.

Adapt_main_4_mc_23: Too much competition in your market
Adapt_Main_5_open: REMOVE THE BURDEN OF HEALTH INSURANCE FROM COMPANIES. We are small enough that we don't *have* to provide it, but our employees don't currently have an affordable alternative, so we provide a basic plan that is pretty not-great. When we had to lay off 3 employees when 100% of our restaurant partners shut down, they lost their health insurance (during the start of a pandemic) at the end of the month. We need a NATIONAL solution to this! As well, small businesses without an HR department or any expertise in this area trying to administer health insurance plans is ridiculous, takes actually a few hours a month of frustrating time (there is a problem every single month of the year -- how to enroll people, what to do when the plan changes, something wrong with the bill, etc.) away from us actually trying to run our business. This is an illogical/crazy thing to have attached to businesses -- everyone needs it, most businesses are not experts in the area, it penalizes small businesses who can't afford to hire someone to manage it, and it causes undue stress for both employers and employees.

Adapt_main_4_mc_24_TEXT: Employment laws for hiring and the insane minimum wage. Also as a small business that has 6 employees that work less than 20 hours a week to have to manage 401k options is terrible. These jobs are supplemental income for my employees and they do not require so much overhead requirements. I also can not continue to pay people sick leave due to covid or any other illness
Adapt_Main_5_open: I need first the government to stop creating rules regulating every aspect of my business. From what I pay my staff to how much time I give them off and if I pay them or not for time off. As a food industry business I expect the government to regulate the safety of the food I supply but to continue to have to provide excessive pay,sick time and 401k (which will start next year) is impossible to afford. Many small business do not have full time employees and provide jobs as supplemental income not a living wage income and to be expected to provide that is a excessive burden on my business.

Adapt_main_3_mc_15_TEXT: We adapted the best we could, did more pick-up and built boxed meals that we didn't do before, but the loss of business was devastating.
Adapt_main_4_mc_17: Lack of access to external funding
Adapt_main_4_mc_23: Too much competition in your market
Adapt_Main_5_open: It is tough to think about, as we are still digging out from last year. The most frustrating part is that the unemployment program kept so many people from looking for our jobs (restaurant/line level) that my dedicated crew who has stuck by me (and myself) are exhausted and hitting our wits end. Yes, we constantly adapt and change (that is the nature of our business), but it is honestly exhausting to think about another potential shut down. I am still digging out of debt and so the most beneficial program would be low cost capital that could be quickly available similar to the PPP last year. Without that we would have been gone. Digging out of debt has been difficult with increased costs and supply chain disruptions. But ultimately exhaustion and customers/new employees that are now becoming so entitled and difficult to work with does make one question, "why are we doing this?" "Is it worth it in the end when we see profit margins slipping even more and the exhaustion that those us of dedicated to our field/craft are feeling?" It would be nice to sign up for one of those hefty signing bonuses and be done with the long hard hours, but dang it-I love our business and our industry. Sorry to ramble on so long-don't know if I necessarily answered the question-other than that having money always makes changes easier.

Demo_main_1_mc_1: Denver (Adams, Arapahoe, Boulder, Broomfield, Clear Creek, Denver, Douglas, Gilpin, and Jefferson)
Bhea_Opres_6_open: Most of the music industry was shut down from the beginning of the pandemic. Some aspects of the industry, like the service I provide, is STILL shut down. After exhausting all my savings, I reluctantly turned to unemployment after not finding any outside help. But UE has been a bit of a nightmare, on top of the guilt I felt about filing, now they are saying they made a mistake on the amount they were paying me & now I'm responsible for repaying the 'overpayment' that wasn't my fault. This past year+ has been a nightmare, my business of 24 years has been shut down & probably won't come back until next year. Not sure how to survive until that happens...
Tech_tool_3_mc_23: Using anti-malware/virus software on all computers used for my business
Tech_inv_4_sum_8_TEXT: I have no $ to spend now
Adapt_main_4_mc_22: Uncertain market demand for your business
Adapt_main_4_mc_27_TEXT: Pandemic destroyed the demand for our service
Adapt_Main_5_open: For my company specifically, the issue was the lockdowns prevented bands from touring. Without bands performing live around the country, my business cannot continue. They are just barely starting to tour now, but not enough yet to get me back up & running, unfortunately. It's just sad, after 24 years of hard work, it's all just suddenly taken away, due to no fault, except maybe Trump for bungling everything about the pandemic & fellow Americans who listened to him and have never taken it seriously. They & COVID have effectively destroyed my livelihood & I've lost my life savings in the process of trying to 'make it through.'

Adapt_Main_5_open: I feel the state definitions could be updated to make room for interactive game development as its own classification. Right now, everything falls under the bucket of "Arts" but games are a strange hybrid of art, technology and entertainment that (looking at 2020 revenues) make over $177.8 billion dollars worldwide, eclipsing all other forms of entertainment by many billions of dollars. This industry is a juggernaut, and where it roots, a huge number of collateral jobs are made. I ask, "Does Colorado like pie? If so, do they want a slice of a $177.8 billion dollar pie?" Because Colorado has all the makings of a great state for this industry, it's just sad that there's practically zero help for any developers who wish to live and create within the state. In 2019 the state lost one of its longest lived (native) game companies, Backflip Studios, without so much as a whimper. What would today have looked like if Backflip Studios could have managed some help in the form of grants or state aid? I would advise giving ample room for growth in this area in the form of tax incentives and large scale grants. The end results would only strengthen Colorado's place as a growing economic bastion.

Demo_main_1_mc_1: Denver (Adams, Arapahoe, Boulder, Broomfield, Clear Creek, Denver, Douglas, Gilpin, and Jefferson)
Bhea_Opres_6_open: We have four sectors: retail, craft classes, coffee & snacks, and photography. Coffee & snacks are fairly stable but very little in-shop business. Our equipment is failiong and service is difficult to find. Craft classes are failing as few people want in-person classes. Retail has fallen off and deliveries are sporadic. Photography is stable and some areas are growing (pet portraits).

Adapt_main_3_mc_12: Marketing methods for promotion, packaging, pricing, product placement or after sales services
Adapt_main_4_mc_17: Lack of access to external funding
Adapt_main_4_mc_21: Difficulties in obtaining government grants or subsides
Adapt_main_4_mc_22: Uncertain market demand for your business
Adapt_Main_5_open: Access to flexible sources of funding is essential to make it through uncertain times. However, as a small business in a rural setting, we are of little interest to major lenders. We are a hub for local craft-persons and artists and losing our venue would have a negative impact on these vendors (south-east Douglas, Elbert, El Paso, and Arapahoe counties), since craft fairs and similar arenas have been getting shut down over the past 18 months or so. With the resurgence of the delta coronavirus, both sides in the politicized debate over masks, vaccines, social distancing, etc, have retreated into their own bubbles and no longer want to sit for a simple conversation in a public coffee shop that might blow up into a confrontation. Our business model *had* been based on getting people into our shop for coffee & snacks or craft classes and then up-selling retail items. People just don't want to sit around in-doors chatting in a larger group any longer, This had been our mechanism for getting traffic into our shop, which is located remotely from any similar sort of business. Any approach that would "go bigger" or "break the covid barrier" would demand either (I think) capital investment in outdoor patio space or targeting one side or the other (pro- or anti- public health measures) and developing that as a brand. Honestly, this seems to be a trend lately in which bars or restaurants differentiate themselves by refusing or embarrassing customers who are masked or vaccinated, on the one hand, or refusing customers who are not masked or vaccinated. Neither of these seem to me to be sustainable business propositions, whether or not COVID kills you or shuts down your business. Perhaps in a couple of years, the bad taste of all of this will have been washed away; but until then, some form of active financial risk mitigation to save small business such as ours would be incredibly useful.

Adapt_main_4_mc_24_TEXT: We were locked down and only about 25% of our patients came back. And, my staff decided unemployment paid better than me -so, I had a huge commercial space and had to move -which led to me being sued for $400k in rent. Thanks for NO support at all...
Adapt_Main_5_open:
Not being locked down again.
If landlords had to give us a rent break - instead of 100% rent even when we didn't have revenue. Now, I have to pay back a huge EIDL loan that I used to pay 100% rent and then for my lawsuit because I couldn't keep paying $8k/month when we were closed. I am closing my locating next month, unfortunately - after 20+ years in practice - I can't take the stress of bills anymore. I work to pay back my EIDL and not pay myself. The last 18 months have been a living hell for me as a small biz owner.

Adapt_main_4_mc_24_TEXT: Lock downs
Adapt_Main_5_open:
Re-defining what a small business is. I have 20 employees, that is a small business. The government defines a small business as 2000 or something ridiculous for the number for employee’s? How is that small? How do I compete for funding or marketing or in the job market on such a small scale. The US is really forcing us mom and pop places out. 
The restaurant sector has also been the main target of being the COVID police. We have seen more mandates than any other sector. Follow the lead and listen to the National Restaurant Association, they have the correct temperature of what is really taking place in the US.

Adapt_Main_5_open: Stop unemployment. All companies are desperate for employees. Our goverment has spent more money on individuals who have used COVID as an excuse, there are many companies who have made provisions for their employees to work from home. In our case, no on needs to come in contact with another individual. Unless they choose to do so. It's not COVID taking down small businesses, it's us Americans. I believe the PPP Loans were providing assistance to those who wanted to work. Maybe not everyone was working 40 hours, although they were working and getting paid for 40 hours. It all goes back to give man a fish and he eats today. Teach a man to fish and you feed him for a life time. I have had direct conversations with individuals who have told me they are making more on unemployement than when they were working.

Demo_main_1_mc_1: Denver (Adams, Arapahoe, Boulder, Broomfield, Clear Creek, Denver, Douglas, Gilpin, and Jefferson)
Bhea_Opres_6_open: I have lost 96+% of my income over the last year due to Covid, and due to health issues due to Covid, cannot rebuild my business the way that I need to. I have applied for multiple grants, loans and was not awarded any of them. I applied for Energize Colorado, and spent over $3,000 on PPE toward the energize grant, but was told they ran out of funding before I was awarded a grant. I am losing PUA unemployment in September and am continuing to try to find other financial assistance to keep my bills paid, but have had no luck or assistance. Due to Energize Colorado, I now have an additional loan (costs) of $3,000+, and will soon have no way to pay any of my bills including the $3,000+ that Energize Colorado cost me. I have lost most of my clients due to being unable to work, and do not know how many I will be able to get back.

Adapt_Main_5_open:
We educate certified registered nurse Anesthetists on how to deliver acute healthcare and about covid 19 intensive care.. They must earn continuing education to remain current in knowledge and licensed by State of Colorado and their national association. During covid we switched to zoom and attracted 80% of attendees to Colorado for a family visit. We lost about $1,500 last Confetence cycle. With this new covid surge and some employers disallowing use of continuing education funds for Zoom conferences we expect sales to drop more this year. If we lose MORE money this year, we may need to close. Colorado will lose visitorship as a result.
Thank you for any help that can be given this year.
Dr. Stephanie May, DNAP, CRNA
Owner, health care educator 
CRNAskiColorado@gmail.com

Adapt_main_4_mc_21: Difficulties in obtaining government grants or subsides
Adapt_Main_5_open:
Lower interest gap funding and bridge loan offerings. Being able to span rough times with external cash flow sources that aren’t predatory and detrimental in the long run because of the interest rates introduced. 


Lowering the revenue requirements for small business administration loans. Currently at $125k/yr for 3 yrs. many sole proprietor business’s operations are under that and fail because they can never get there without external funds available. Or the funds they can get, high interest loans or credit cards, end up putting them in a snowball of debt that’s not easily overcome by the initial small profits seen from a start up. 


This is especially true is service industry businesses.

Adapt_main_4_mc_24_TEXT: Completing applications for available small business funding was onerous complicated and involved excessive amounts of time. So there was a 'tradeoff' question EVERY TIME one of these grant, loan, PPP opportunities came up.
Adapt_Main_5_open: A hub that provides the most needed services requested by small businesses - HR Processes, Legal Advice, partnership opportunities (eg. large contractors need skill sets of small businesses), vetting / clearing- house for qualified expertise, and on and on. A RESILIENCY HUB. I've actually wanted to start one of these myself for about a decade! There are so many agencies to interact with presently, that it's overwhelming to actually take advantage of the services available - the HUB could play a role in facilitating access, consulting and guiding small businesses to the right place.

Adapt_Main_5_open: How on earth was my business supposed to survive when I was mandated to close for several months? Then had to hold "classes" at 10-50% capacity for another year. Then I had to force my clients to exercise in a mask? I applied for EVERY grant available but since I hire independent contractors I qualified for nothing. Never mind the fact that my business partner and I have been working 60+ hours a week, with no pay to keep our business afloat. I am more than happy to provide you with all the grant rejection letters I received. In the mean time, people are making thousands of dollars for NOT working. This money would be life saving for my business. My small female owned fitness business has completely fallen through the cracks of the one size fits all relief efforts.

Adapt_main_4_mc_27_TEXT: Negative politics about COVID safety protocols resistance in area has negatively impacted our company unity. HAs been haED MAINTAINING
Adapt_Main_5_open: We would be out of business were it not for the two PPP loans we received. Very much appreciated, along with a Facebook grant and a number of smaller COVID assistance grants. As a newspaper, we rely on businesses advertsiing, and for them to advertise, they need to be healthy enough to do so. We are usually several months behind the recovery of other sectors accordingly. I am concerned about needing to lay off people in the event of another lockdown if there is no additional PPP funding available. We had a strong 2Q in 2021, but 1Q and 3Q so far are still decreasing in revenue over 2020, which was a big decrease over 2019. We are heading into a big sales push for 3Q and 4Q, so hopefully that, plus the upcoming election will pull us out of the fire.

Adapt_main_4_mc_21: Difficulties in obtaining government grants or subsides
Adapt_Main_5_open: Overall better understanding of how my particular industry works. The most difficult part of entertainment, specifically games, is that the product takes years to complete with little guarantee of return. It's a high risk industry and for the most part requires capital to keep the lights on and ensure project completion (and even future projects). Independent game developers have adapted to run as lean as possible. Distributed work forces, free software, and labor that (for the most part) works on development as a labor of love outside their regular day jobs. All this makes for sluggish development and slow growth of an industry that, in all other places and respects, makes more money year over year than all other entertainment combined. Colorado would do well to invest in game development and make special exception to this very robust hybrid industry of programmers and visual artists.
